title: How does new media technology impact society? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let’s look at the times that had the greatest technological innovation. Recorded jazz became popular in the 1920’s. Due partly to the fact that sound and radio engineering made tremendous strides. AM broadcast radio, ‘ 78 RPM vinyl records with cactus thorns as needles. Later, 45’s and still later 331/3 rpm. We still use some of the same technologies that were developed then; a flat disk with a hole in the middle for non-linear audio playback. Topologically similar to the Edison wax cylinder but much more useful. It still exists in the form of spinning hard disk drives. During the cold war, in 1969, We actually put a human being on the moon and returned him to earth unharmed. Not because it was easy. But because it was hard. It was a challenge. Part of that challenge was to beat the Soviets to the moon. But we did it. What have we done since then? People have died in space. Plenty of unmanned missions. In 1969 NASA was cheered. Since then NASA has since become a plaything of politicians and conspiracy theorists. In my own work as a film and video colorist, the work is based on ‘color science’ which in turn is based on ‘color spaces’. (checks NDA. OK) Theatrical distribution of films uses a color space called x,y,z. It is based on work that was done in 1931. I kid you not. All of those oversimplified examples happened in the wake of large scale World Wars. I’m not advocating for a third world war. The last two were bad enough. We still have some innovation going on. But it is nowhere near the scale that it once was. Large scale innovation is flattening out. And with it, our growth, our economy, and our expectations for the future. The US seems to now be in the business of exporting movies, TV shows, business models, culture, technology, media. The whole world seems to have become what they used to call in econ 101 “An economy of taking in each other’s washing.” But let’s look on the bright side. Humanity is down but not out. We’ll figure out how to have innovation without a World War. Or die trying. Some of our best entertainment came out of the Great Depression. It may have been a depression but it was a great one. So keep on smiling, ’Cause when you’re smiling, the whole world smiles with you.
